level1_breath.title: Introduction to Meditation
level1_breath.subtitle: Learn the fundamentals of mindful meditation

level1_breath.focusPoint: The natural rhythm of breathing in and out

challenges.2: You don't need to empty your mind

1.title: Find Your Seat
1.description: Sit on a chair, cushion, or cross-legged on the floor. Your comfort matters most.

2.title: Posture Check
2.description: Keep your spine straight but not rigid. Imagine a string gently pulling your head toward the sky.

3.title: Hand Placement
3.description: Rest your hands on your knees or in your lap. Let your shoulders relax down and back.

4.title: Eyes
4.description: You can close your eyes or keep them softly focused on a point in front of you.

sessionTips.1: Start with just noticing when you breathe in and when you breathe out
sessionTips.2: When your mind wanders, gently bring attention back to your breath
sessionTips.3: Be patient and kind with yourself‚Äîthis is a skill that develops over time
sessionTips.4: Every moment of awareness counts, no matter how brief

breathingPrep.instruction: Take 5 slow, deep breaths to settle in. Breathe in for 4 counts, out for 4 counts.

1.message: Notice the sensation of breath at your nostrils or belly

2.message: Mind wandered? That's perfectly normal. Gently return to the breath.

level1_body_scan.title: Relax with Body Awareness
level1_body_scan.subtitle: Release tension from head to toe
level1_body_scan.intention: Systematically relax each part of your body
level1_body_scan.focusPoint: Sensations in different body parts as you scan through them

challenges.1: Falling asleep is okay‚Äîyour body needs rest
challenges.2: You might not feel much in some areas, and that's normal
challenges.3: Tension might increase before it releases

1.title: Lie Down Comfortably
1.description: Lie on your back with arms at your sides, palms facing up. Use a pillow if needed.

2.title: Legs Uncrossed
2.description: Let your feet fall naturally to the sides. No need to hold any position.

3.title: Temperature
3.description: Cover yourself with a blanket if you tend to feel cold during rest.

sessionTips.1: Don't try to force relaxation‚Äîjust observe what you feel
sessionTips.2: Notice warmth, coolness, tingling, or nothing at all
sessionTips.3: If you fall asleep, consider this a successful relaxation
sessionTips.4: There's no need to remember the exact order‚Äîthe voice will guide you

breathingPrep.instruction: Take 3 deep sighs. Breathe in through your nose, sigh out loudly through your mouth.

1.message: Allow each body part to become heavy and relaxed

level5_vipassana.title: Insight Through Direct Observation
level5_vipassana.subtitle: See the three characteristics: impermanence, unsatisfactoriness, non-self
level5_vipassana.intention: Investigate the nature of experience with precision and equanimity
level5_vipassana.focusPoint: Arising and passing of sensations, thoughts, and mental states

challenges.1: Strong sensations (pain, heat, tingling) will arise
challenges.3: Insights can be destabilizing; take breaks if needed

1.title: Traditional Posture
1.description: Sit in your established meditation posture. Stillness supports insight.

2.title: Mountain-Like
2.description: Embody stability and presence, unmoved by passing phenomena.

sessionTips.2: Observe how everything arises, changes, and passes away
sessionTips.3: When pain arises, investigate its edges, quality, and impermanence
sessionTips.4: Maintain equanimity‚Äînot seeking pleasant or avoiding unpleasant

breathingPrep.instruction: Settle with 10 minutes of breath awareness before beginning the scan.

1.message: Notice: arising, persisting, passing away. Everything is in flux.

2.message: Strong sensations are opportunities for insight, not obstacles.

3.message: Equanimity is the key. Observe, don't react.

settings.scientificSourcesDescription: Research behind the benefits of meditation
settings.scienceIntro: The benefits of meditation have been confirmed in numerous scientific studies. Here are key publications:
settings.source1Title: Mindfulness practice leads to increases in regional brain gray matter density
settings.source1Desc: 8-week MBSR program increased gray matter density in brain regions associated with memory and emotional regulation.
settings.source2Title: A randomized controlled trial of mindfulness meditation versus relaxation training
settings.source2Authors: Jain et al., 2007 - Annals of Behavioral Medicine
settings.source2Desc: Mindfulness significantly reduced anxiety and rumination compared to other relaxation techniques.
settings.source3Title: Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction and Health Benefits
settings.source3Authors: Grossman et al., 2004 - Journal of Psychosomatic Research
settings.source3Desc: Meta-analysis of 20 studies confirmed positive effects of MBSR on mental and physical health.
settings.breathingIntro: Controlled breathing affects the autonomic nervous system. Research shows slow, rhythmic breathing activates the parasympathetic response. Note: optimal breathing patterns vary between individuals based on factors like lung capacity and heart rate.
settings.breathSource1Title: How Breath-Control Can Change Your Life: A Systematic Review on Psycho-Physiological Correlates of Slow Breathing
settings.breathSource1Authors: Zaccaro et al., 2018 - Frontiers in Human Neuroscience
settings.breathSource1Desc: Comprehensive review of 15 studies showing slow breathing (under 10 breaths/min) increases parasympathetic activity, improves emotional control, and enhances psychological well-being.
settings.breathSource2Title: The Effect of Diaphragmatic Breathing on Attention, Negative Affect and Stress in Healthy Adults
settings.breathSource2Authors: Ma et al., 2017 - Frontiers in Psychology
settings.breathSource2Desc: Study of 40 participants showed deep diaphragmatic breathing significantly reduced cortisol levels and improved sustained attention compared to control group.
settings.breathSource3Title: Cardiac vagal control, emotion regulation, and executive function in youth with anxiety disorders
settings.breathSource3Authors: Vasilev et al., 2018 - Journal of Affective Disorders
settings.breathSource3Desc: Research demonstrating the link between respiratory sinus arrhythmia (heart rate variability during breathing) and emotional regulation capacity.

welcome.text: Meditation is a training of attention and awareness. Research suggests that regular sessions (at least 10-12 minutes daily for 8 weeks) can support stress reduction and improved focus.

whatIs.title: What is meditation?
whatIs.text: Meditation is the training of consciously focusing your attention. It's not about silencing thoughts, but about noticing them without judgment. It's mental training that anyone can learn.

benefits.title: Benefits of meditation
benefits.text: Research suggests regular meditation can support mental and physical well-being:

howTo.title: How to start?

bullets.2: Close your eyes and focus on your breath
bullets.3: When your mind wanders, gently return attention to breath

instructionsScreen.breathingIntro: Breathing techniques help calm the mind and prepare for meditation. Choose the pattern that suits your situation.

box.name: For Stress
box.description: Calms and focuses the mind. Perfect for stress and anxiety.
steps: Inhale through nose for 4 seconds
Hold breath for 4 seconds
Exhale through mouth for 4 seconds
Hold breath for 4 seconds
Repeat for 4-5 cycles

478.name: For Sleep
478.description: Deep relaxation before bed. Helps you fall asleep.
steps: Inhale through nose for 4 seconds
Hold breath for 7 seconds
Exhale through mouth for 8 seconds
Repeat 3-4 times
Allow your body to relax

equal.name: For Beginners
equal.description: Simple pattern for beginners. Easy to learn.
steps: Inhale through nose for 4 seconds
Exhale through nose for 4 seconds
Maintain an even, calm rhythm
Focus on natural breathing
Continue for 2-3 minutes

calm.name: For Energy
calm.description: Fast and energizing breath. Boosts energy.
steps: Quick inhale through nose for 2 seconds
Quick exhale through mouth for 2 seconds
Maintain a dynamic rhythm
Feel the energy surge
Continue for 1-2 minutes

breathingExercises.readyMessage: When you're ready, press the button below to start the exercise.

instructionsScreen.buildSessionIntro: Combine techniques to create a complete meditation session. Start with settling, move through a main technique, and end with integration.

bodyScan.name: Body Scan
bodyScan.description: Progressive relaxation technique moving attention through the body
steps: Lie down comfortably or sit in a relaxed position
Close your eyes and take a few deep breaths
Bring attention to your toes, notice any sensations
Slowly move attention up through feet, ankles, calves
Continue scanning upward: thighs, hips, abdomen
Move through chest, shoulders, arms, hands
Scan neck, face, and top of head
Hold awareness of your whole body for a moment
Gently open your eyes when ready

breathFocus.name: Breath Focus
breathFocus.description: Concentration technique using the breath as an anchor
steps: Sit comfortably with a straight back
Close your eyes or soften your gaze
Notice the natural rhythm of your breathing
Feel the breath at your nostrils, chest, or belly
When mind wanders, gently return to the breath
Count breaths if helpful (1-10, then repeat)
Continue for your chosen duration
End with a few deeper breaths

lovingKindness.name: Loving Kindness (Metta)
lovingKindness.description: Cultivating compassion and goodwill toward self and others
steps: Sit comfortably and close your eyes
Begin with yourself: "May I be happy, may I be healthy"
Visualize someone you love, send them kindness
Think of a neutral person, extend kindness to them
Consider someone difficult, wish them well
Expand to all beings everywhere
Rest in the feeling of universal compassion

mindfulObservation.name: Mindful Observation
mindfulObservation.description: Present moment awareness through sensory observation
steps: Choose an object (flower, candle flame, etc.)
Sit comfortably and bring full attention to the object
Notice colors, shapes, textures in detail
Observe without judgment or analysis
When mind wanders, return to observing
Expand awareness to sounds and sensations
Conclude with gratitude for the present moment
